'''Banco de Gaia''' is an English [[electronic music]] project, formed in 1989 by '''Toby Marks''' (born 1964, [[South London]], England).

The music of Banco de Gaia is mostly categorized as [[ambient dub]] and [[downtempo]]. Marks works to cross genres, often using [[Arabic]] and Middle Eastern [[sampling (music)|samples]] against a bass heavy [[reggae]], rock, or [[trance music|trance]] rhythm to produce deeply textured tracks that progress layer upon layer.{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}}

==History==
In 1978, Marks began his musical career as a drummer in a [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]] band.

Marks moved to [[Portugal]] in 1986 and played [[The Beatles|Beatles]] music for tourists. He first delved into electronic music in 1989, when he bought a [[digital sampler]]. The first tune he recorded on it was called "Maxwell House".

Having cut his teeth on the early 1990s ambient dub compilations, in 1994 he released his first studio album ''Maya'' on [[Planet Dog]] records,<ref name="Larkin90">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Virgin Encyclopedia of Nineties Music]]|editor=Colin Larkin|editor-link=Colin Larkin (writer)|publisher=[[Virgin Books]]|date=2000|edition=First|isbn=0-7535-0427-8|page=33}}</ref> which was submitted to the [[Mercury Music Prize]] on its release. It was followed in 1995 by the critically acclaimed ''[[Last Train to Lhasa]]''. Both albums reached No. 1 in the [[UK Indie Chart]] and featured in the Top 40 of the [[UK Albums Chart]]. In the following decade, Banco De Gaia released ''Live at Glastonbury'', ''Big Men Cry'', ''The Magical Sounds of Banco De Gaia'', ''Igizeh'' and ''You Are Here''.<ref name="Larkin90"/>

In 1997, Banco De Gaia put together a five-piece band that included Ted Duggan (drums), Ashley Hopkins (bass), Larry Whelan (wind synth, saxophone and ethnic flutes), and Gary Spacey-Foot (percussion and saxophones). The band reduced in number to just Marks, Duggan, and Hopkins in 1999, and then just Marks and Duggan from 2000 until 2003, when Marks went back to being a solo artist.

On 20 September 2009, Banco De Gaia played an album launch show for his album ''Memories Dreams Reflections'' at [[Dingwalls]] in London. This show was to celebrate 20 years of Banco De Gaia. Marks was joined on stage by three members from the original five-piece band: Hopkins, Whelan, and Duggan and vocalist Maya Preece, who sang on the latest album.

He released a studio album ''Apollo'' on 8 April 2013, on his own Disco Gecko Recordings.<ref>Parsons, Gary. [http://freq.org.uk/reviews/banco-de-gaia-apollo/ "Banco de Gaia – Apollo"]. ''Freq''.</ref><ref>[http://www.tinymixtapes.com/music-review/banco-de-gaia-apollo "Apollo: Disco Gecko; 2013"]. By Olga Drenda, ''Tiny Mixtapes''.</ref>

In 2015, Banco (Toby Marks) returned to playing with a live three-piece band, Ted Duggan (drums)<ref name="badfingeruk.com">{{Cite web|url=http://www.badfingeruk.com/home|title=BADFINGER Featuring Bob Jackson Official Website|website=Badfingeruk.com}}</ref> and James Eller (bass).<ref name="jameseller.com">{{Cite web|url=https://www.jameseller.com/|title=HOME|website=Jameseller.com}}</ref>

On 7 October 2016, he released his ninth studio album ''The 9th of Nine Hearts'',<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://banco.co.uk/album/the-9th-of-nine-hearts/|title=The 9th of Nine Hearts|website=Banco.co.uk}}</ref> featuring collaborations with [[Sophie Barker]] ([[Zero 7]]), [[Tim Bowness]] ([[No-Man]]), [[Dick Parry]] ([[Pink Floyd]]) and his band.

== Discography ==
=== Early cassettes ===
*''Medium'' (World Bank, 1991)
*''Freeform Flutes and Fading Tibetans'' (World Bank, 1992)
*''Deep Live'' (World Bank, 1992)
These first three albums existed only on tape and are no longer being sold due to [[copyright]] issues with several of the [[sampling (music)|samples]] used on them.

=== Albums ===
*''[[Maya (Banco de Gaia album)|Maya]]'' ([[Planet Dog]], 1994) – [[UK Albums Chart|UK]] No. 34<ref name="British Hit Singles & Albums">{{cite book
| first= David
| last= Roberts
| year= 2006
| title= British Hit Singles & Albums
| edition= 19th
| publisher= Guinness World Records Limited 
| location= London
| isbn= 1-904994-10-5
| page= 41}}</ref> 	 		
*''[[Last Train to Lhasa]]'' (Planet Dog, 1995) – UK No. 31<ref name="British Hit Singles & Albums"/>
*''[[Big Men Cry]]'' (Planet Dog, 1997)
*''[[The Magical Sounds of Banco de Gaia]]'' (Six Degrees Records, 1999)
*''[[Igizeh]]'' (Six Degrees, 2000)
*''[[You Are Here (Banco de Gaia album)|You Are Here]]'' (Six Degrees, 2004)
*''[[Farewell Ferengistan]]'' (Six Degrees, 2006)
*''[[Memories Dreams Reflections]]'' (2009)
*''Apollo'' (2013)<ref>[http://www.coremagonline.com/reviews/banco-de-gaia-apollo-review.html " Banco De Gaia - Apollo Review"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151023043223/http://www.coremagonline.com/reviews/banco-de-gaia-apollo-review.html |date=23 October 2015 }}. Written by Gideon Thomas ''Core Magazine''.</ref><ref>[http://globetronica.org/reviews/album/banco-de-gaia-apollo "Banco De Gaia Apollo"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160204230645/http://globetronica.org/reviews/album/banco-de-gaia-apollo |date=4 February 2016 }}. ''Globetronica''.</ref>
*''Ollopa:Apollo Remixed'' (2013)
*''Maya: 20th Anniversary Edition'' (2014)
*''Last Train to Lhasa: 20th Anniversary Edition'' (2015)
*''The 9th of Nine Hearts'' (2016)
*''Big Men Cry: 20th Anniversary Edition'' (2017)
*''The Magical Sounds of Banco de Gaia: 20th Anniversary Edition'' (2019)
*''Igizeh: 20th Anniversary Edition (2020)''

=== Live albums ===
*''Live at Glastonbury'' ([[Planet Dog]], 1996)
*''Live at Glastonbury: 20th Anniversary Edition'' (2016)

=== Compilation albums ===
*''[[10 Years (Banco de Gaia album)|10 Years]]'' (2002)
*''10 Years Remixed'' (2003)
*''Songs From The Silk Road'' (2011)
*''Rewritten Histories Vol.1 1992 – 1995'' (2011)
*''Rewritten Histories Vol.2 1996 – 2001'' (2012)
*''Rewritten Histories Vol.3 2002 – 2013'' (2014)
*''30 Times Around The Sun'' (2019)

*''Desert Wind'' (1993)
*''[[Maya (Banco de Gaia album)|Heliopolis]]'' (1994)

*''[[Drunk As a Monk Mixes]]''
*''[[I Love Baby Cheesy]]'' (1999)
*''Obsidian'' (2000)
